title: Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options header has not been set.

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,

The following host "profile-photos-user-content.hackerone.com" does not set the x-content-type-options header to nosniff. If a malicious user is able to upload an image with script content (Possible within the comments metadata) Internet Explorer (up till IE8) might render the content as Javascript and execute malicious code.

The problem is more severe since the photos are uploaded to a subdomain of hackerone.com.

Cheers,

Hey @nikbugbounty, thanks for submitting this. The `profile-photos-user-content.hackerone.com` is completely sandboxed and hosted outside of our production environment. It is a subdomain of our root domain `hackerone.com`, but I am not aware of any working cross-domain problems here. Also, we enforce a download to make sure content does not get rendered inline.

Did you manage to get this working in a proof of concept?

Thanks!

Nah, didn't try it actually. I should have.

The response to your other statements are listed below:

1.  Cross-domain issue - IE (Internet Explorer) behaves differently. If you set the cookie domain to hackerone.com, IE will still send the cookie to profile-photos-user-content.hackerone.com similar to if the domain was set to .hackerone.com (Notice the preceding dot before hackerone.com) .Here are some links that describe its behaviour:
https://jacob.hoffman-andrews.com/README/why-you-need-a-www/
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2009/08/20/wininet-ie-cookie-internals-faq.aspx

2. The images didn't download for me because the content-disposition is not set to attachment. I tried it on all new versions of major browsers. Not sure if that is what you meant.

Thanks.

Moving user uploaded files to a completely separate domain was already on our roadmap. I'll raise this with the team and see if we have to reprioritize that transition.

One more question: the session cookie is http only, so even though IE somehow manages to send this cookie to all subdomains, an attacker who is able to render HTML on `profile-photos-user-content.hackerone.com`, would not be able to access that cookie with JS, right?

Hey @michiel,

Yup your last statement is correct, but an attacker can do a lot more with an XSS than just steal cookies.

Even if there wasn't an XSS this would still be an issue under certain circumstances. The way that the Hackerone application is configured/designed will cause IE to send auth cookies to all subdomains. If all the subdomains are controlled by you now and in the future, this may not be an issue. But, if any of the subdomains point to third-parties, they would be receiving auth cookies as well because of the way IE is designed. Any malicious third-party could log into hackerone using a stolen cookie associated with someone's user account. Basically, auth cookies will be leaked to parties that are not under your control.

Recommendation:

1. Upload files to a separate domain as mentioned by you.
2. Host your site on www.hackerone.com instead of hackerone.com to prevent IE from leaking cookies to sub-domains. This will also make it future-proof in the event you decided to use sub-domains to point to third-parties.
3. the hackerone application shouldn't allow files with .HTML extension to be uploaded to 
profile-photos-user-content.hackerone.com unless it is required.


Cheers,
Also add the content-type option header just to cover all bases.

We moved the storage of avatars and cover photos to a completely separate domain, hackerone-user-content.com. The files are basically served from an Amazon S3 bucket, but Amazon does not allow us to send `X-Content-Type-Options`, so we are unable to implement that suggestion. However, since we moved from a subdomain to a completely separate domain, I think we're fine. Thank you again for reporting this!
